column1:
impetuous /imˈpɛtʃuːs/
Examples: Her impetuous decision to quit the job surprised everyone.; He drove the car in an impetuous manner, nearly causing an accident.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Making arbitrary decisions, especially in an impulsive and forceful manner.
column2: Characterized by sudden violence or vehemence.

column1:
succumbed /səkˈsʌmbɪd/
Examples: Thai culture as in many other Asian cultures, is succumbing to the influence of westernization.; Succumb to pneumonia.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To yield to an overpowering force or overwhelming desire.
column2: To give up, or give in.

column1:
eminently /\u02c8\u025bm\u026an\u0259ntli/
Examples: Everyone supported the nominee because she was eminently qualified.,"Part of Speech: adverb
Definition: In an eminent or prominent manner.

transfixed /trænˈsˌfɪkst/
Examples: The horror movie transfixed the audience; The arrow transfixed the deer; She was transfixed by the performance,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To render motionless, by arousing terror, amazement or awe
column2: To pierce with a sharp pointed weapon
column4: Rendered motionless by completely focused attention, rapt, entranced, mesmerized

column1:
visceral /\u02c8v\u026as\u0259\u0279\u0259l/
Examples: No examples provided,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Of or relating to the viscera—internal organs of the body.
column2: Having to do with the response of the body as opposed to the intellect, as in the distinction between feeling and thinking.

column1:
stifled /ˈstɪfɪld/
Examples: The army stifled the rebellion.; The heat was stifling the children.; The heat felt stifling.; Two firemen tragically stifled in yesterday's fire when trying to rescue an old lady from her bedroom.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To interrupt or cut off
column2: To repress, keep in or hold back
column6: To treat a silkworm cocoon with steam as part of the process of silk production
column7: That has been interrupted, suppressed etc

column1:
chastened /ˈtʃæstən/
Examples: After the scandal, the politician was chastened by public outrage.; The coach chastened the players with strict training.; The mentor chastened the student by pointing out mistakes.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To punish (in order to bring about improvement in behavior, attitude, etc.)
column5: To punish or reprimand for the sake of improvement

column1:
provincials /prəˈvɪnʃəlz/
Examples: The provincials in the council argued for local autonomy.;The book is filled with provincials who complain about city life.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A person belonging to a province
column3: A monastic superior, who, under the general of his order, has the direction of all the religious houses of the same fraternity in a given district, called a province of the order.

column1:
rigorous /\u02c8\u0279\u026a\u0261\u0259\u0279\u0259s/
Examples: a rigorous execution of law; a rigorous winter.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Showing, causing, or favoring rigour

rekindled /rɪˈkaɪndɪld/
Examples: After being abroad for a decade, when he came back he rekindled his obsession with cricket.,"Part of Speech: verb

column2: To be kindled or ignited again

column1:
complacency kəmˈpleɪsənsi
Examples: No examples provided.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A feeling of contented self-satisfaction, especially when unaware of upcoming trouble.

tactile /\u02c8t\u00e6kta\u026al/
Examples: The tactile sensor on the robot allowed it to navigate the dark room.,"Part of Speech: adjective

column2: perceptible to the sense of touch. Used for feeling. Of or relating to the sense of touch.

column1:
oar /əʊ/
Examples: He is a good oar.,"Part of Speech: noun

Definition: A type of lever used to propel a boat, having a flat blade at one end and a handle at the other, and pivoted in a rowlock atop the gunwale, whereby a rower seated in the boat and pulling the handle can pass the blade through the water by repeated strokes against the water's resistance, thus moving the boat.
column4: An oar-like swimming organ of various invertebrates.
column6: to travel with, or as if with, oars.

column1:
bohemian /boʊˈhimi.ən/
Examples: He was considered a bohemian for his unconventional lifestyle; The bohemian artist refused to follow conventional norms,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: An unconventional or nonconformist artist or writer
column2: Unconventional, especially in habit or dress

column1:
attestation /ˈeɪ.tə.stə.ʃən/
Examples: The attestation of the signature was verified by the notary.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A thing that serves to bear witness, confirm, or authenticate
column4: The process, performed by accountants or auditors, of providing independent opinion on published financial and other business information of a business, public agency, or other organization.
column5: (of a language, word, word form, or word meaning) An appearance in print or otherwise recorded on a permanent medium.

column1:
menial /\u02c8mi\u02d0ni.\u0259l/
Examples: a menial wretch,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A servant, especially a domestic servant.
column2: A person who has a subservient nature.
column3: Of or relating to work normally performed by a servant.
column4: Of or relating to unskilled work.

column1:
secularized /səˈkɜːrəlɑɪzd/
Examples: The new policy secularized the university's campus by removing religious symbols.,"Part of Speech: verb

bourgeoisie /\u02ccb\u028a\u0259(\u0279)\u0292w\u0251\u02d0\u02c8zi\u02d0/
Examples: The bourgeoisie owns most of the factories in the city.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A class of citizens who were wealthier members of the third estate.

ethnicities /ɪθˈnɪsɪtiz/
Examples: Ethnicities are often celebrated during cultural festivals.; Understanding the various ethnicities in the city helps promote inclusivity.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The common characteristics of a group of people, especially regarding ancestry, culture, language or national experiences.

contemporary /k\u0259n\u02c8t\u025bm.p(\u0259).\u0279i/
Examples: Cervantes was a contemporary of Shakespeare.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Someone or something living at the same time, or of roughly the same age as another.
column2: Something existing at the same time.
column3: From the same time period, coexistent in time.

column1:
lucrative /ˈluːkrətɪv/
Examples: The company found the new market to be lucrative.; Investing in real estate can be lucrative.,"Part of Speech: adjective

patriarchal /ˌpæ.tri.əˈkrɑːl/
Examples: The society was still patriarchal, with men holding most positions of power.;Her perspective is rooted in patriarchal norms.,"Part of Speech: adjective

column3: Relating to a system run by males, rather than females.

column1:
palatable /ˈpæl.ə.tə.bəl/
Examples: For some instant noodles make a palatable, if not especially nutritious, meal.;The agreement was palatable to both of them.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Pleasing to the taste, tasty.

subtlest /ˈsʌb.tlɪst/
Examples: The difference is subtle, but you can hear it if you listen carefully.,"Part of Speech: adjective

column5: (of a person or animal) Cunning, skillful.
column9: of low density or thin consistency.
